translated: YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra, fascicle 100
Expounded by Maitreya Bodhisattva
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on imperial command
In the chapter on collecting activities, the fifth part on selecting and collecting the matters of discipline, part two. Next, for bhiká¹£us who diligently study according to the Vinaya,
They should thoroughly understand five matters.
What are the five?
First, thoroughly understanding the matter.
Second, thoroughly understanding the offense.ğŸ”½Third, thoroughly understanding the individual.
Fourth, thoroughly understanding the benefit of attracting others.
Fifth, thoroughly understanding harm.
What is meant by thoroughly understanding the matter?
It refers to the five matters such as the aggregates, which have already been explained in the ÅšrÄvaka Grounds.
What is meant by thoroughly understanding the offense?
It refers to bhiká¹£us who diligently study according to the Vinaya.
They thoroughly understand what they have transgressed in five ways.ğŸ”½First, they thoroughly understand the causes and conditions of committing an offense.
Second, they thoroughly understand the arising of committing an offense.ğŸ”½Third, they thoroughly understand the matter of committing an offense.
Fourth, they thoroughly understand the preparatory actions of committing an offense.
Fifth, thoroughly understanding the completion of the offense.
Thoroughly understanding the causes and conditions of the offense means:ğŸ”½Either due to causes of greed,
causes of anger,
or causes of delusion,
one commits various offenses.
Thoroughly understanding the origin of the offense means:ğŸ”½Either there are offenses that originate from the body but not from speech or mind,
or there are offenses that originate from speech but not from the body or mind,ğŸ”½or there are offenses that originate from the mind but not from the body or speech,
or there are offenses that originate from the body and mind but not from speech,ğŸ”½or there are offenses that originate from speech and mind but not from the body,
or there are offenses that originate from the body and speech but not from the mind,
or there are offenses that originate from the body, speech, and mind.
There are no offenses committed by the mind alone.
One should confess and repent of them to others.
One should only be sincere and deeply protect oneself.
It is like a bhiká¹£u who gives rise to various kinds of sensual thoughts and other unwholesome thoughts.
As for thoroughly understanding the criminal offense,
There are two kinds of criminal offenses.
The first is that which is counted as a sentient being.
The second is that which is not counted as a sentient being.
As for thoroughly understanding the criminal offense and the performance of it,
There are two kinds of performance of criminal offenses.
The first is the performance of an improper action.
The second is the performance of a proper action.
As for thoroughly understanding the completion of the criminal offense,
It means that in this place, a means is established.
In this very place, it is completed.
There is no turning back in the middle.
For this reason, the offense is fully committed.

In the means of committing the other offenses, the grave offenses, the offenses requiring confession in the assembly, and the offenses that are committed by means, one commits a downfall and a misdeed.
In those means and in one's own category, it is completed.
In the means of committing the offense of a downfall,
One also commits a misdeed.
The four kinds of offenses are called offenses with remainder.
The category of offenses requiring confession in the assembly is called an offense without remainder.
If a crime is committed due to having knowledge,
it is called not accumulated.
Or, because it is revealed from others,
it is also not accumulated.
The opposite of this
is not non-accumulated.
If a crime has already been confessed to others in accordance with the Dharma and repented of by skillful means,
it is called already revealed.
The opposite of this
is called not yet revealed.
If a crime is committed with the intention to repent later,
it is called having a vow.
The opposite of this
is called having no vow.
If a crime
is established as a transgression by the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, in the Vinaya of the PrÄtimoká¹£a,
it is called having a rule.
The opposite of this
is called having no rule.
If a crimeğŸ”½is not determined in relation to a certain type of person,
or in relation to a certain time,
and was not previously established in a general way without distinction,
it should be known that this crime is called equalized.
The opposite of this is
called non-equal movement.
What is the thorough understanding of the individual?
It should be known by five aspects.
First, by the difference in practice.
Second, by the difference in the assembly.
Third, by the difference in increase and decrease.
Fourth, by the difference in realization.
Fifth, by the difference in contemplation.
As for the difference in practice,
it means that by thoroughly understanding the differences in practices such as greed, etc.,
those differences exist.
Their characteristics should be known as in the ÅšrÄvaka Stage.
As for the difference in the assembly,
it means that by thoroughly understanding the differences in the seven assemblies such as bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, etc., those differences exist.
As for the difference in increase and decrease,
it means that for a certain type of individual,ğŸ”½either one who has left the household life in a noble family,
or one who has left the household life in a wealthy family,
or one who has a handsome appearance,
the others are not like this.
Furthermore, there is a certain type of individual,
They are well-versed and knowledgeable, their speech is complete and perfect, they have great wisdom and great blessings.
They firmly and vigorously protect their pure precepts.
They feel much remorse for even minor transgressions.
They are well aware of what is transgressed and what is to be emerged from.
The other type is not like this.
If one can thoroughly understand such matters,
one should know that it is said that there are differences in the thorough understanding of increase and decrease, and therefore there are differences in that [thorough understanding].
As for the difference in realization,
it refers to being able to thoroughly understand the seven types of distinctions from the one liberated according to faith up to the final one.
The eight types of distinctions from the path of the fruit of stream-entry up to the final fruit of arhatship.
Such distinctions in individuals
are explained in the same way as in the ÅšrÄvaka Stages.
As for the difference in observation,
it refers to the individual who can bring up offenses.
They should observe well the one who brings up offenses,
and then they should bring it up to remind them.
It means observing whether the person who is being accused has affection and respect for oneself.
The details should be understood as explained in the sutra.
The person who is accusing should also be well examined.
Is this person a foolish man, insane, confused, or is he accusing illegally and wanting to harm me?
The details should be understood as explained in the sutra.
Is this person wise, not insane, not confused, and has good qualities?
The details should be understood as explained in the sutra.
Moreover, regarding the person who is being accused,
one should properly examine whether to accuse or not.
In this way, observing the distinctions of the person,
it should be known as the thorough understanding of the person.
What is the thorough understanding of attracting benefits?
It means being able to thoroughly understand the three kinds of attracting benefits.
What are the three?
First, attracting one's own benefits and offerings.
Second, the meaning and benefit of bringing out the offenses of others' bodies.
Third, the meaning and benefit of bringing in the Sangha's expulsion of the precepts-breaking and peace and happiness.
As for the meaning and benefit of bringing in one's own body's offerings,
If the substance of all offerings is pure,
This is called true.
If the substance of all offerings is pure and suitable for use,
Not uselessly hoarding many provisions and resources.
This is called the meaning and benefit of being able to bring in.
If all offerings are not excessive at the time and suitable for abiding and enjoyment,
This is called timely.
If all offerings are also being brought in by other bhiká¹£us,
This is called having companions.
These companions do not bring in the schism of the Saá¹…gha,
And are called being apart from the schism of the Saá¹…gha.
If the meaning and benefit of the offerings that are brought in,
Are endowed with these five branches and abide in right mindfulness,
With an undefiled mind one should enjoy them.
Such bringing in of the meaning and benefit of offerings,
Is called being without offense.
As for the meaning of benefiting others by bringing them out of offenses,
if the offense committed is actually carried out by them,
this is called true.
If one also knows for oneself that one can cause them to leave unwholesome states and place them in wholesome states,
this is called being able to bring benefit.
When others expound the Dharma, serve and respect the elders, and properly engage in caring for the sick,
it is not appropriate to bring up their offenses.
This is called timely.
If one brings up their offenses and the other bhiká¹£us assist as companions,
this is called having companions.
These causes and conditions are not able to lead to the destruction of the Saá¹ƒgha.
This is called the fifth purity.
If the meaning of benefiting others by bringing them out of offenses is brought,
endowed with these five branches, abiding in right mindfulness with an undefiled mind,
like a kind and virtuous friend, with gentle words one should bring others out of offenses and benefit them.
As for bringing others out of offenses and benefiting them,
as for bringing the Saá¹ƒgha out of the happiness and benefit of banishing those who violate the precepts,
one should know it is also like this.
The difference is as follows.
If the reason for the expulsion is that the one who is expelled
does not give life to the one who expels, or does not cause the destruction of the saá¹ƒgha's dwelling place because of this,
or does not cause damage to the stÅ«pa because of this,
and does not cause harm to other practitioners of pure conduct,
this is called leading to benefit.
The opposite of this
should be known as leading to no benefit.
What is the thorough knowledge of harm?
There are five kinds of harm in the present lifeğŸ”½that ordinary people pursue,
that the foolish pursue,
that the wise avoid,
that even though they are not actually insane, they act like the insane,
up to only having false and deceptive delays,
and there is no increase in any benefit.
What are the five?
There is one kind who grieves over death,
and torments themselves in countless ways over those who have perished.
This is called the first harm in the present life,
that ordinary people pursue, and so on in detail.
There is another type who, fortunately, has other easy means of livelihood.
But in the crossroads and great markets,
they dissect their limbs and joints, and their lives are almost at an end.
They suffer evil and hardship, and maintain themselves by their own efforts.
This is called the second kind of harm in the present life.
It is the destination of ordinary beings, and so on, in detail.
There is another type who, by nature, is stingy and greedy, and is obscured by the defilement of stinginess.
Fortunately, they have various means of livelihood,
but they maintain themselves with great difficulty.
This is called the third kind of harm in the present life.
It is the destination of ordinary beings, and so on, in detail.
What is the defilement of stinginess?
It refers to the eight defilements of stinginess.
The first is the defilement of stinginess due to past habits of stinginess and lack of generosity.
The second is the defilement of stinginess due to great concern for one's body and life in the present.
The third is the defilement of stinginess due to lack of familiarity with compassion and a weak compassionate mind towards sentient beings who live and interact with one's own kind.
The fourth is the defilement of stinginess due to seeing the field of blessings as lacking virtue and violating proper conduct.
Fifth, the stain of stinginess that arises from the thought that all possessions are difficult to obtain.
Sixth, the stain of stinginess that is regretful at three times.
Seventh, the stain of stinginess that sees only the merits of all treasures and does not see their faults.
Eighth, the stain of stinginess that is a mistaken dedication of giving.
One should know that these are called the eight kinds of stains of stinginess.
Moreover, there is a type of person who loves the heavenly realms and desires to be born in the heavens.
But they do not know the path to rebirth in the heavens as it truly is.
They harm themselves by fasting, throwing themselves into fires, jumping off high cliffs, and so forth.
This is called the fourth kind of harm in the present life.
The destinations of ordinary beings are explained in detail.
Moreover, there is a type of person who loves purity.
But they do not know the path to purity as it truly is.
They say that by practicing painful methods one can attain purity.
They harm themselves in countless ways.
This is called the fifth kind of harm in the present life.
The destinations of ordinary beings are explained in detail.
These five kinds of harm in the present life,
are based on the Vinaya and diligent study by bhiká¹£us.
One should quickly abandon them.
Next, based on the Vinaya, a diligent and studious bhiká¹£u
accomplishes five dharmas.
Those who have not yet generated faith will generate it.
Those who have already generated faith will cause it to increase.
What are the five?
First, the perfection of precepts.
Second, the perfection of right views.
Third, the perfection of proper conduct.
Fourth, the perfection of pure livelihood.
Fifth, the perfection of being far removed from mutual disputes.
The perfection of precepts is roughly of ten kinds.
As explained in the ÅšrÄvaka Grounds.
Namely, first, properly upholding them without being too lax or too strict.
And so on, explaining in detail.
The perfection of right views is roughly of five kinds.
First, the complete abandonment of the view of the transitory collection and the extreme views.
Second, the complete abandonment of the view that deprecates and denies wrong views.
Third, the complete abandonment of the views that grasp at views, the view of holding a view as paramount, and the view of holding morality and asceticism as paramount.
Fourth, because they have already permanently eliminated the view that regards as auspicious that which is not auspicious.
Fifth, because they have already permanently eliminated the various inverted views that regard what is not conditioned as conditioned, and what is conditioned as not conditioned.
The perfection of rules also has five aspects.
That is to say, either based on timely duties, one should do what should be done.
Or based on wholesome activities, one should do what should be done.
Or based on deportment, one should do what should be done.
In accordance with worldly customs and the Vinaya, one should know the rules in detail as explained in the ÅšrÄvaka Grounds.
The perfection of pure livelihood also has five aspects.
That is to say, one is able to stay far away from the five dharmas that give rise to wrong livelihood such as deceit.
One should know their characteristics as explained in the ÅšrÄvaka Grounds.
The perfection of avoiding mutual disputes has six aspects in brief.
That is to say, because one is free from the six roots of disputes.
Here, the six roots of disputes are
anger, resentment, and so forth.
They are explained in detail in the sÅ«tras.
Moreover, one should know that the establishment of the six roots of disputes is based on the six sense bases.
What are the six bases?
First, the aspect of harm;
Second, delighting in concealing one's faults and being arrogant and obstinate;
Third, the current practice of desire for offerings and respect;
Fourth, violating the superior precepts;
Fifth, violating the superior concentration;
Sixth, violating the superior wisdom.
It should be known that based on the first base, the first root of dispute is established.
Up to based on the sixth base, the sixth root of dispute is established.
There is a type of person who is well-known to the assembly.
From other places, they obtain many offerings.
Because of this, they violate [the precepts].
They delight in concealing the offenses they have committed.
They do not want others to know about their transgressions.
There are bhiká¹£us who, having understood this,
face one, two, or many and bring up their transgressions.
Because of this, they are entirely sorrowful and distressed, burning their body and mind.
Moreover, because of being grasped by arrogance, one gives rise to much distress.
Fearing that others may again reproach them in front of the assembly,
in this way, that person first conceals their offense.
This is called concealment.
Moreover, they give rise to the afflictions of arrogance.
These two together are called the arrogance of delighting in concealing one's faults and being grasped by arrogance.
This establishes the root of disputes.
There are also bhiká¹£us who, out of respect for material gain, give rise to the desire to engage in present activities.
Seeing that others have abundant wealth and are well-known, possessing great blessings and virtue,
they then become intimate with them, respectfully serving them.
It is neither out of love nor respect, nor is it out of a delight in the Dharma.
It is solely for the sake of material gain and respect.
Thinking in this way, they acceptğŸ”½upright forbearance,
and take gentleness as their basis.
Teacher, I.
In that place, I have freedom to do as I please.
They have done much for me.
But I have done nothing for them.
Thus, he thinks and accepts.
He has sharp wisdom, delights in cultivating blessings, and takes fellow practitioners as his companions.
He makes them do all the duties of the Saá¹…gha and other matters.
I alone am carefree and at ease, abiding by myself.
Thus, he may violate the precepts.
When fellow practitioners are properly questioning him,
he is not clear and speaks of other matters instead.
This is called practicing deceit and flattery.
Conflicts arise from this cause and condition.
The other corresponding characteristics should be understood as appropriate.
The opposite of this,
there are five kinds of dharmas,
that cause those who are not yet faithful to increase in lack of faith,
and cause those who are already faithful to quickly change.
Next, relying on the Vinaya, a diligent and studious bhiká¹£u accomplishes five powers.
In all ways, he is of equal mind and correctly practices all the preparatory efforts.
What are the five powers?
First, the power of preparatory effort.
Second, the power of intention.
Third, the power of understanding.
Fourth, the power of right knowledge.
Fifth, the power of straightforwardness.
If one delights in learning all the bodily parts and properly trains in the trainings,
and with utmost respect for the trainings, in order to subdue oneself and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a,
this should be known as the power of practice.
If one commits an offense, one quickly gets out of it due to one's intention.
This should be known as the power of intention.
If one, regarding the precepts,
from time to time asks the Tripiá¹­aka masters,
and the good sons who cherish themselves can also reveal what should be practiced,
this should be known as the power of understanding.
Having heard from others, if one truly and correctly accepts what is true and real,
and if one truly understands the false vinaya, the semblance of true Dharma, and the evil words that go against the nature of dharmas,
even if one does not personally request what is not yet understood,
But because of their extensive learning, they do not block or allow anything in the Buddha's teachings.
They are able to contemplate for themselves what accords with the nature of Å›ramaá¹‡as and what goes against it.
Having understood this, they are able to practice correctly and to abandon [what is to be abandoned] as appropriate.
This should be known as the power of right wisdom.
If one has the power of faith and understanding, one is free from deception and flattery.
One does not have the slightest false discrimination.ğŸ”½One does not increase and engage in practice in what is allowed in small part.
One does not decrease and engage in practice in what is allowed in large part.
One's practice is neither increased nor decreased.
This is the first self-rejoicing.
Later, one causes oneself and others to abide in peace and happiness and practices the correct practice.
One does not deceive others.
This should be known as the power of straightforwardness.
Furthermore, based on the training in the Vinaya,
one should know the distinctions in the five types of individuals.
There is a type of person
in the well-taught Dharma and Vinaya,
who, relying on the renunciant life, is just about to set out.
Although they wish to set out, they have not yet gone forth.
They give rise to afflictions and wrongly seek desire.
For this reason, they do not go forth.
Furthermore, there is a type of person who, having gone forth,
because of the intensity of afflictions, thinks of committing offenses.
Because of this, they have much regret.
They give rise to afflictions and wrongly seek desire.
Furthermore, there is a type of person who, having gone forth,
does not take joy in the renunciant life.ğŸ”½They are about to give up their training and return to the home life.
And they give rise to regret about going forth.
They think like this:
This is not good for me, namely going forth.
They give rise to afflictions and wrongly seek desire because of these two conditions.
Furthermore, there is a type of person who, having gone forth,
because of the difficulty of maintaining life, does not think of violating their training.
They will love and delight in leaving the household life and diligently cultivate pure conduct until the end of their lives.
They will not give rise to afflictions or evil thoughts and searches due to these two conditions.
These four kinds of people are ordinary beings.
There is also one kind.
It refers to those who are still learning but have not yet attained liberation.
Based on this,
in the future, they will attain the first mind and wisdom liberation, and progress through realization.
They will truly understand.
This is called the fifth kind of person.
This fifth kind, compared to the previous fourth kind of ordinary beings,
due to being well-disciplined, lovable, and having the liberation of those still learning,
there is a difference in the realization and progress towards liberation in the future.
It should be known that this is already on the path of seeing the truth.

Among them, the first three kinds of people,ğŸ”½according to their circumstances, should correctly eliminate the afflictions and evil thoughts and searches that arise from setting out on the path,ğŸ”½from the arising of regret,
and from both of these.
They should correctly understand the liberation above.
The fourth should be correctly understood only in the later and higher liberations.
If one can be like this in everything, it will be equal and equal.
It should be known that there are three kinds of wrong practices in learning.
There is one kind of person.
First seeking nirvana, he delights in leaving the household life.
After leaving the household life, he is carried away by the love and enjoyment of the wonderful desires of the heavens.
The precepts he upholds are dedicated to good destinies.
He is content with merely guarding the precepts.
This is called the person who is externally bound, the first wrong practice in superior precepts.
There is another kind of person.
He is not content with merely guarding the precepts.
He is able to attain one of the supramundane concentrations.
He deeply becomes attached to this concentration.
He does not strive to seek the realization of the noble truths.
This is called the person who is internally bound, the second wrong practice in superior concentration.
There is another kind of person.
This refers to those who are still learners, who have already seen the traces of the truth.
Because they abide in negligence, they do not attain nirvana in this very life.
One should know that this is called the third wrong practice regarding superior wisdom.
This treatise on the essential points of the discipline that accords with the objects and wisdom of the Mahayana
All the rest should be understood according to this method.
In the section on the essential points of the basic topics, the preface to the essential points of the basic topics is discussed as follows: The essential points of the Vinaya have been explained.
The essential points of the treatises.
Namely, the essential points of the sutras and the essential points of the Vinaya.
Collectively and briefly named as one essential points of the treatises.
Although there are no separate essential points of the treatises,
However, in order to briefly include
The mixed teachings on samsara, nirvana, defilement, and purity,
I will now further explain the essential points of the treatises that distinguish the characteristics of the Dharma.
The uddana says:
The other must be explained by others, this is not explained by this.
from here on it will be extensively discussed.
If there are any dharmas that should be explained to others,
it is necessary to first generally indicate them by other approaches.
Then, by other approaches, they should be explained in detail afterwards.
If it is like this, it is called in accordance with the correct principle.
It is not that in this approach they are first generally indicated,
and then by this approach they are explained in detail afterwards.
It is like first generally indicating What are the conditioned? and then explaining in detail They are the five aggregates.
If it is like this, it is called in accordance with the correct principle.
It is not that first What are the conditioned? is generally indicated, and then They are the conditioned is explained in detail afterwards.
All should be understood in this way.
In brief, by two aspects,
one should know the establishment and analysis of the characteristics of dharmas in the Abhidharma.
First, briefly introducing the matter;
second, relying on this briefly introduced matter, it will be extensively discussed afterwards.
The matter of the defiled aspect of cyclic existence and the matter of the purified aspect of cessation and extinction.
What is the defiled aspect of cyclic existence?
Namely, the essence, support, object, and function of the six consciousnesses.
If the aggregates, realms, and sense bases are events.
If the events of dependent origination and proper and improper conditions.
If the events of the three feelings.
If the events of the three times.
If the events of the four conditions.
If the events of various actions.
If the events of afflictions.
If the events of the three realms.
Namely, the desire realm, etc.
If the events of the ten existences.
Namely, the existence of desire,
the existence of form,
the existence of the formless,ğŸ”½the existence of hell beings,ğŸ”½the existence of animals,
the existence of hungry ghosts,
the existence of gods,
the existence of humans,
the existence of karma,
and the intermediate existence.
Because of the differences in attracting and leading to the good and evil destinies through the separation from desire.
If the events of the eleven abodes of consciousness.
Namely, by combining the four abodes of consciousness with the seven abodes of consciousness.
If the events of the nine abodes of sentient beings.
As explained in detail in the sutras.
If the events of the five destinies.ğŸ”½If the events of the four kinds of birth.
If the events of the four kinds of entry into the womb.
If it is the four things of obtaining one's own body,
if it is the four things of nourishment,
if it is the four things of speech,
if it is the four things of receiving the Dharma,
if it is the four things of perversion,ğŸ”½if it is the thing of the truth of suffering,
if it is the thing of the truth of the cause [of suffering],
this kind of thing,
is called the brief introduction to the things of the category of transmigration and defilement.
What are the things of the category of cessation and purification?
It refers to the thing of the truth of cessation,ğŸ”½if it is the thing of the truth of the path,
if it is the thing of meditative absorption,
if it is the thing of various knowledges,
if it is the thing of the merits that are drawn forth by this,
if it is the thing of the seven kinds of right Dharma,
if it is the thing of observing the seven kinds of right thought,
if it is the thing of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment,
if it is the thing of the four kinds of practice,
if it is the thing of the four kinds of Dharma practice,
if it is the thing of Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ,
if it is the thing of the four kinds of cultivation of concentration,
if it is the thing of the three kinds of meritorious actions,
if it is the thing of the three trainings,
if it is the thing of the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a,
if it is the thing of the four kinds of purity of realization,
If it is the matter of the four noble lineages,
if it is the matter of the three vehicles,
if it is the matter of the four gates,
this kind of matter,
is called the brief introduction to the matter of the purification of cessation.
The establishment of the extensive explanation of this kind of matter
according to what is appropriate,
as explained before in the various stages and the various aspects of the teachings,
one should know their characteristics.
In brief, all matters
in total there are five kinds of matters:
first, mental matters;
second, matters of mental factors;
third, matters of form;
fourth, matters of factors not directly associated with the mind;
fifth, unconditioned matters.
How is it that based on this brief introduction to matters, the extensive explanation will be given later?
It is because of four aspects that the matters are extensively explained.
What are the four?
First, because of the difference in categories;
second, because of the difference in essence;
third, because of the difference in interpretation;
fourth, because of the difference in types.
The differences in the explanations of the characteristics of the different aspects.
One should understand their characteristics as explained in the chapter on the classification of teachings.
The differences in categories are of eight kinds.
First, establishing the differences in existence, non-existence, sameness, and difference.
Second, establishing the differences in realms and stages.
Third, establishing the differences in time periods.
Fourth, establishing the differences in spatial locations.
Fifth, establishing the differences in continuities.ğŸ”½Sixth, establishing the differences in states.
Seventh, establishing the differences in categories.
Eighth, establishing the differences in principles.
Due to these eight kinds of differences,
in all matters and categories,
one should understand them accordingly.
How are the differences in existence, non-existence, sameness, and difference established?
In brief, there are three kinds of existence:
First, real existence;
second, provisional existence;
third, ultimate existence.
What is real existence?
It refers to those that can be expressed, have names, and have things that can be obtained.
This name operates without obstruction regarding the object.
It does not sometimes operate and sometimes not operate.
One should know that this is called the brief explanation of real existence.
Just as in a collection of dharmas such as form,
The characteristics of walls, houses, armies, forests, grasses, trees, clothing, food, etc. are established.
These characteristics only operate in this collection.
They retreat from the others.
The characteristics of form, etc. operate in all places.
Therefore, the characteristics that are explained are really existent.
One should know that the characteristics that are explained by others are nominally existent.
Moreover, this nominal existence is roughly of six kinds.
First, nominal existence as a collection;
Second, nominal existence as a cause;
Third, nominal existence as a result;
Fourth, nominal existence as an object of activity;
Fifth, nominal existence as a state;
Sixth, nominal existence as a dependent thing.
Nominal existence as a collection means
In order to easily understand and comprehend the worldly language,
In the general characteristics of the five aggregates, etc.,
The concepts of self, sentient beings, pudgala, living beings, etc. are established.
This concept only manifests this aggregate.
Therefore, it is said to be nominally existent as an aggregation.
As for nominal existence as cause,

As for nominal existence as the object of activity,

The uddÄna says:
First, the various grounds and various bases, next, the truths, wisdom, and preparatory practices,
SamÄdhi, faculties, paths, antidotes, practices, and cultivation,
Contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas, various fruits, and causes and conditions,
Establishing the pudgala, and finally, complete knowledge.
There are nine kinds of grounds.
What are the nine?ğŸ”½First, the ground of provisions.
Second, the ground of skillful means.
Third, the ground of contemplation and practice.
Fourth, the ground of seeing.
Fifth, the ground of cultivation.
Sixth, the ground of training.
Seventh, the ground of no-training.
Eighth, the ground of sages.
Ninth, the ground of ordinary beings.
First, one should accumulate supramundane provisions.
Next, one diligently cultivates skillful means to exhaust the contaminants.ğŸ”½Next, during the cultivation of the factors conducive to penetration, one correctly contemplates the truths.
Next, one is able to enter the certainty of correct liberation.
Next, one gradually realizes the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Among them, the first three are the grounds of training.
The fourth fruit is the stage of no-more-learning. Having already realized separation from birth, one gradually ascends the path of all worlds.
It is called the stage of cultivation.
It comprehensively includes the seen.
The stages of learning and no-more-learning are called the stage of the noble ones.
The rest are all called the stage of ordinary beings.
If one has not yet cultivated the preparatory practices,
if one has already cultivated the preparatory practices,
if one has already become free from desire,
all ordinary beings have nine bases.
They are able to exhaust all contaminations.
What are the nine?
They are the preliminary concentration,
the first meditative absorption,
the intermediate meditative absorption,
the remaining three meditative absorptions,
and the three formless [absorptions].
Excluding the peak of existence.
There are also four noble truths.

There are also ten knowledges.

the conventional knowledge,
the knowledge of others' minds,
the knowledge of suffering, etc.,
the knowledge of elimination, and the knowledge of non-production.
This is extensively distinguished in the ÅšrÄvaka Stage.
Moreover, there are five kinds of preparatory efforts for the yoga practitioner.
The first is for the sake of entering into the correct nature of birth.
The second is for the sake of attaining the fruit of the upper [realms].
The third is for the sake of advancing and detaching from desire.
The fourth is for the sake of changing faculties.
The fifth is for the sake of attracting merit.
There are also three kinds of samÄdhi for yoga practitioners.
The first is the samÄdhi of emptiness.
The second is the samÄdhi of wishlessness.
The third is the samÄdhi of signlessness.
There are also three kinds of faculties for those who progress towards and abide in the fruits of all practices.
The first is the faculty of 'desiring to know what is unknown'.
This is the faculty for those who progress towards the fruit of the stream-enterer.
The second is the faculty of 'knowing'.
This is the faculty for those who progress towards the fruit of the arhat, starting from the fruit of the stream-enterer.
The third is the faculty of 'fully knowing'.
This is the faculty for those who abide in the fruit of the arhat.
There are also nine paths.
What are the nine?ğŸ”½The first is the worldly path.
The second is the supramundane path.
The third is the path of preparation.
The fourth is the uninterrupted path.
The fifth is the path of liberation.
The sixth is the path of progress.
The seventh is the inferior path.
The eighth is the middling path.
The ninth is the superior path.
As for the mundane path,
it is by means of this that one is able to realize the severance of the various afflictions of the mundane realm,
or else one is not able to realize severance,
and is able to go to the good destinies or to the evil destinies.
As for the supramundane path,
it is by means of this that one is able to realize the final severance of the various afflictions.
As for the path of preparation,
it is the diligent cultivation of the preparations in order to sever the afflictions.
As for the uninterrupted path,
it is the correct severance of the afflictions.
As for the path of liberation,
it is the attainment of liberation immediately after the severance.
As for the path of progress,
it is the subsequent generation of superior preparations.
As for the inferior path,
it is that which is able to counteract the superior afflictions.
As for the middling path,
it is that which is able to counteract the middling afflictions.
As for the superior path,
it is that which is able to counteract the inferior afflictions.
There are also four kinds of antidotes.
The first is the antidote of disgust and destruction.
The second is the antidote of cutting off and extinguishing.
The third is the antidote of upholding.
The fourth is the antidote of distancing and separating.
There are also sixteen aspects.
Namely, contemplating the four truths as impermanent, etc.
As explained above.
There are also eight kinds of cultivation of these antidotes and aspects.
The cultivation of these should be observed in the same way as the stages of concentration and the stages of Å›rÄvakas.
There are also two categories that encompass all dharmas.
The first is contaminated dharmas.
The second is uncontaminated dharmas.
These two dharmas should be understood as already explained above.
There are also five fruits.
The first is the fruit of retribution.
The second is the fruit of outflow.
The third is the fruit of separation.
The fourth is the fruit of human effort.
The fifth is the fruit of dominance.
There are also ten causes.
The first is the cause of following speech.
The second is the cause of dependence.
The third is the cause of attraction.
The fourth is the cause of inclusion.
The fifth is the cause of production.
Sixth, the initiating cause.
Seventh, the cause of specific differentiation.
Eighth, the cause of the same activity.
Ninth, the contradictory cause.
Tenth, the non-contradictory cause.
There are also four conditions.
First, the causal condition.
Second, the immediately preceding condition.
Third, the object condition.
Fourth, the dominant condition.
All such effects, causes, and conditions,
Have been explained in the Bodhisattva Stages and other texts.
There are also seven kinds of persons,
Namely, those who follow faith, etc.
There are also six kinds of arhats,
Namely, those who are liable to regress, etc.
There are also eight kinds of persons,
Namely, those who practice the four approaches and abide in the four fruits.
This should be understood as in the ÅšrÄvaka Stages.
There are also six kinds of thorough cognition,
First, the thorough cognition of the contaminated truths in the undetermined stage,
Second, the thorough cognition of the contaminated truths in the determined stage,ğŸ”½Third, the thorough cognition of the uncontaminated and unconditioned truths,
Fourth, the thorough cognition of the contaminated and conditioned uncontaminated truths,
Fifth, the thorough knowledge of the lower fetters.
Sixth, the thorough knowledge of the upper fetters.
There are also two kinds of ultimate:
First, the ultimate of knowledge.
Second, the ultimate of elimination.
As for the ultimate of knowledge,
It refers to the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
From this point onward, for the sake of eliminating afflictions, there is no more that needs to be known.
As for the ultimate of elimination,
It refers to the thorough elimination of all afflictions.
Due to the elimination of those,
One perfectly attains the liberation of the mind and the liberation by wisdom.
